CommandDoccommentNode.comment: `conv` is the syntax category for a "conv tactic", where "conv" is short for conversion. A conv tactic is a program which receives a target, printed as `| a`, and is tasked with coming up with some term `b` and a proof of `a = b`. It is mainly used for doing targeted term transformations, for example rewriting only on the left side of an equality. -/

AtomNode.val: `conv` is the syntax category for a "conv tactic", where "conv" is short for conversion. A conv tactic is a program which receives a target, printed as `| a`, and is tasked with coming up with some term `b` and a proof of `a = b`. It is mainly used for doing targeted term transformations, for example rewriting only on the left side of an equality. -/

AtomNode.trailing: -- Order is important: a missing `conv` proof should not be parsed as `{ <missing> }`, -- automatically closing goals

CommandDoccommentNode.comment: The `*` occurrence list means to apply to all occurrences of the pattern. -/

AtomNode.val: The `*` occurrence list means to apply to all occurrences of the pattern. -/

CommandDoccommentNode.comment: A list `1 2 4` of occurrences means to apply to the first, second, and fourth occurrence of the pattern. -/

AtomNode.val: A list `1 2 4` of occurrences means to apply to the first, second, and fourth occurrence of the pattern. -/

CommandDoccommentNode.comment: An occurrence specification, either `*` or a list of numbers. The default is `[1]`. -/

AtomNode.val: An occurrence specification, either `*` or a list of numbers. The default is `[1]`. -/
" := "
") "

CommandDoccommentNode.comment: `with_annotate_state stx t` annotates the lexical range of `stx : Syntax` with the initial and final state of running tactic `t`. -/

AtomNode.val: `with_annotate_state stx t` annotates the lexical range of `stx : Syntax` with the initial and final state of running tactic `t`. -/
"with_annotate_state "

CommandDoccommentNode.comment: `skip` does nothing. -/

AtomNode.val: `skip` does nothing. -/

CommandDoccommentNode.comment:
Traverses into the left subterm of a binary operator.
In general, for an `n`-ary operator, it traverses into the second to last argument. It is a synonym for `arg -2`. -/

AtomNode.val:
Traverses into the left subterm of a binary operator.
In general, for an `n`-ary operator, it traverses into the second to last argument. It is a synonym for `arg -2`. -/

CommandDoccommentNode.comment:
Traverses into the right subterm of a binary operator.
In general, for an `n`-ary operator, it traverses into the last argument. It is a synonym for `arg -1`. -/

AtomNode.val:
Traverses into the right subterm of a binary operator.
In general, for an `n`-ary operator, it traverses into the last argument. It is a synonym for `arg -1`. -/

CommandDoccommentNode.comment: Traverses into the function of a (unary) function application. For example, `| f a b` turns into `| f a`. (Use `arg 0` to traverse into `f`.) -/

AtomNode.val: Traverses into the function of a (unary) function application. For example, `| f a b` turns into `| f a`. (Use `arg 0` to traverse into `f`.) -/

CommandDoccommentNode.comment: Reduces the target to Weak Head Normal Form. This reduces definitions in "head position" until a constructor is exposed. For example, `List.map f [a, b, c]` weak head normalizes to `f a :: List.map f [b, c]`. -/

AtomNode.val: Reduces the target to Weak Head Normal Form. This reduces definitions in "head position" until a constructor is exposed. For example, `List.map f [a, b, c]` weak head normalizes to `f a :: List.map f [b, c]`. -/

CommandDoccommentNode.comment: Expands let-declarations and let-variables. -/

AtomNode.val: Expands let-declarations and let-variables. -/

CommandDoccommentNode.comment: Puts term in normal form, this tactic is meant for debugging purposes only. -/

AtomNode.val: Puts term in normal form, this tactic is meant for debugging purposes only. -/

CommandDoccommentNode.comment: Performs one step of "congruence", which takes a term and produces subgoals for all the function arguments. For example, if the target is `f x y` then `congr` produces two subgoals, one for `x` and one for `y`. -/

AtomNode.val: Performs one step of "congruence", which takes a term and produces subgoals for all the function arguments. For example, if the target is `f x y` then `congr` produces two subgoals, one for `x` and one for `y`. -/

CommandDoccommentNode.comment: * `arg i` traverses into the `i`'th argument of the target. For example if the target is `f a b c d` then `arg 1` traverses to `a` and `arg 3` traverses to `c`. The index may be negative; `arg -1` traverses into the last argument, `arg -2` into the second-to-last argument, and so on. * `arg @i` is the same as `arg i` but it counts all arguments instead of just the explicit arguments. * `arg 0` traverses into the function. If the target is `f a b c d`, `arg 0` traverses into `f`. -/

AtomNode.val: * `arg i` traverses into the `i`'th argument of the target. For example if the target is `f a b c d` then `arg 1` traverses to `a` and `arg 3` traverses to `c`. The index may be negative; `arg -1` traverses into the last argument, `arg -2` into the second-to-last argument, and so on. * `arg @i` is the same as `arg i` but it counts all arguments instead of just the explicit arguments. * `arg 0` traverses into the function. If the target is `f a b c d`, `arg 0` traverses into `f`. -/
"arg "

CommandDoccommentNode.comment: `ext x` traverses into a binder (a `fun x => e` or `∀ x, e` expression) to target `e`, introducing name `x` in the process. -/

AtomNode.val: `ext x` traverses into a binder (a `fun x => e` or `∀ x, e` expression) to target `e`, introducing name `x` in the process. -/

CommandDoccommentNode.comment: `change t'` replaces the target `t` with `t'`, assuming `t` and `t'` are definitionally equal. -/

AtomNode.val: `change t'` replaces the target `t` with `t'`, assuming `t` and `t'` are definitionally equal. -/
"change "

CommandDoccommentNode.comment: `delta id1 id2 ...` unfolds all occurrences of `id1`, `id2`, ... in the target. Like the `delta` tactic, this ignores any definitional equations and uses primitive delta-reduction instead, which may result in leaking implementation details. Users should prefer `unfold` for unfolding definitions. -/

AtomNode.val: `delta id1 id2 ...` unfolds all occurrences of `id1`, `id2`, ... in the target. Like the `delta` tactic, this ignores any definitional equations and uses primitive delta-reduction instead, which may result in leaking implementation details. Users should prefer `unfold` for unfolding definitions. -/

CommandDoccommentNode.comment:
* `unfold id` unfolds all occurrences of definition `id` in the target. * `unfold id1 id2 ...` is equivalent to `unfold id1; unfold id2; ...`.
Definitions can be either global or local definitions.
For non-recursive global definitions, this tactic is identical to `delta`. For recursive global definitions, it uses the "unfolding lemma" `id.eq_def`, which is generated for each recursive definition, to unfold according to the recursive definition given by the user. Only one level of unfolding is performed, in contrast to `simp only [id]`, which unfolds definition `id` recursively.
This is the `conv` version of the `unfold` tactic. -/

AtomNode.val:
* `unfold id` unfolds all occurrences of definition `id` in the target. * `unfold id1 id2 ...` is equivalent to `unfold id1; unfold id2; ...`.
Definitions can be either global or local definitions.
For non-recursive global definitions, this tactic is identical to `delta`. For recursive global definitions, it uses the "unfolding lemma" `id.eq_def`, which is generated for each recursive definition, to unfold according to the recursive definition given by the user. Only one level of unfolding is performed, in contrast to `simp only [id]`, which unfolds definition `id` recursively.
This is the `conv` version of the `unfold` tactic. -/

CommandDoccommentNode.comment:
* `pattern pat` traverses to the first subterm of the target that matches `pat`. * `pattern (occs := *) pat` traverses to every subterm of the target that matches `pat` which is not contained in another match of `pat`. It generates one subgoal for each matching subterm. * `pattern (occs := 1 2 4) pat` matches occurrences `1, 2, 4` of `pat` and produces three subgoals. Occurrences are numbered left to right from the outside in.
Note that skipping an occurrence of `pat` will traverse inside that subexpression, which means it may find more matches and this can affect the numbering of subsequent pattern matches. For example, if we are searching for `f _` in `f (f a) = f b`: * `occs := 1 2` (and `occs := *`) returns `| f (f a)` and `| f b` * `occs := 2` returns `| f a` * `occs := 2 3` returns `| f a` and `| f b` * `occs := 1 3` is an error, because after skipping `f b` there is no third match. -/

AtomNode.val:
* `pattern pat` traverses to the first subterm of the target that matches `pat`. * `pattern (occs := *) pat` traverses to every subterm of the target that matches `pat` which is not contained in another match of `pat`. It generates one subgoal for each matching subterm. * `pattern (occs := 1 2 4) pat` matches occurrences `1, 2, 4` of `pat` and produces three subgoals. Occurrences are numbered left to right from the outside in.
Note that skipping an occurrence of `pat` will traverse inside that subexpression, which means it may find more matches and this can affect the numbering of subsequent pattern matches. For example, if we are searching for `f _` in `f (f a) = f b`: * `occs := 1 2` (and `occs := *`) returns `| f (f a)` and `| f b` * `occs := 2` returns `| f a` * `occs := 2 3` returns `| f a` and `| f b` * `occs := 1 3` is an error, because after skipping `f b` there is no third match. -/
"pattern "

CommandDoccommentNode.comment: `rw [thm]` rewrites the target using `thm`. See the `rw` tactic for more information. -/

AtomNode.val: `rw [thm]` rewrites the target using `thm`. See the `rw` tactic for more information. -/

CommandDoccommentNode.comment: `simp [thm]` performs simplification using `thm` and marked `@[simp]` lemmas. See the `simp` tactic for more information. -/

AtomNode.val: `simp [thm]` performs simplification using `thm` and marked `@[simp]` lemmas. See the `simp` tactic for more information. -/
" only"
" ["

CommandDoccommentNode.comment: `simp?` takes the same arguments as `simp`, but reports an equivalent call to `simp only` that would be sufficient to close the goal. See the `simp?` tactic for more information. -/

AtomNode.val: `simp?` takes the same arguments as `simp`, but reports an equivalent call to `simp only` that would be sufficient to close the goal. See the `simp?` tactic for more information. -/
" only"

CommandDoccommentNode.comment:
`dsimp` is the definitional simplifier in `conv`-mode. It differs from `simp` in that it only applies theorems that hold by reflexivity.
Examples:
```lean example (a : Nat): (0 + 0) = a - a := by conv => lhs dsimp rw [← Nat.sub_self a] ``` -/

AtomNode.val:
`dsimp` is the definitional simplifier in `conv`-mode. It differs from `simp` in that it only applies theorems that hold by reflexivity.
Examples:
```lean example (a : Nat): (0 + 0) = a - a := by conv => lhs dsimp rw [← Nat.sub_self a] ``` -/
" only"
" ["
" only"

CommandDoccommentNode.comment: `simp_match` simplifies match expressions. For example, ``` match [a, b] with | [] => 0 | hd :: tl => hd ``` simplifies to `a`. -/

AtomNode.val: `simp_match` simplifies match expressions. For example, ``` match [a, b] with | [] => 0 | hd :: tl => hd ``` simplifies to `a`. -/

CommandDoccommentNode.comment: Executes the given tactic block without converting `conv` goal into a regular goal. -/

AtomNode.val: Executes the given tactic block without converting `conv` goal into a regular goal. -/
" => "

CommandDoccommentNode.comment: Focuses, converts the `conv` goal `⊢ lhs` into a regular goal `⊢ lhs = rhs`, and then executes the given tactic block. -/

AtomNode.val: Focuses, converts the `conv` goal `⊢ lhs` into a regular goal `⊢ lhs = rhs`, and then executes the given tactic block. -/
" => "

CommandDoccommentNode.comment: Executes the given conv block without converting regular goal into a `conv` goal. -/

AtomNode.val: Executes the given conv block without converting regular goal into a `conv` goal. -/
" => "

CommandDoccommentNode.comment: `{ convs }` runs the list of `convs` on the current target, and any subgoals that remain are trivially closed by `skip`. -/

AtomNode.val: `{ convs }` runs the list of `convs` on the current target, and any subgoals that remain are trivially closed by `skip`. -/

CommandDoccommentNode.comment: `(convs)` runs the `convs` in sequence on the current list of targets. This is pure grouping with no added effects. -/

AtomNode.val: `(convs)` runs the `convs` in sequence on the current list of targets. This is pure grouping with no added effects. -/

CommandDoccommentNode.comment: `rfl` closes one conv goal "trivially", by using reflexivity (that is, no rewriting). -/

AtomNode.val: `rfl` closes one conv goal "trivially", by using reflexivity (that is, no rewriting). -/

CommandDoccommentNode.comment: `done` succeeds iff there are no goals remaining. -/

AtomNode.val: `done` succeeds iff there are no goals remaining. -/

CommandDoccommentNode.comment: `trace_state` prints the current goal state. -/

AtomNode.val: `trace_state` prints the current goal state. -/

CommandDoccommentNode.comment: `all_goals tac` runs `tac` on each goal, concatenating the resulting goals, if any. -/

AtomNode.val: `all_goals tac` runs `tac` on each goal, concatenating the resulting goals, if any. -/
"all_goals "

CommandDoccommentNode.comment: `any_goals tac` applies the tactic `tac` to every goal, and succeeds if at least one application succeeds. -/

AtomNode.val: `any_goals tac` applies the tactic `tac` to every goal, and succeeds if at least one application succeeds. -/
"any_goals "

CommandDoccommentNode.comment: * `case tag => tac` focuses on the goal with case name `tag` and solves it using `tac`, or else fails. * `case tag x₁ ... xₙ => tac` additionally renames the `n` most recent hypotheses with inaccessible names to the given names. * `case tag₁ | tag₂ => tac` is equivalent to `(case tag₁ => tac); (case tag₂ => tac)`. -/

AtomNode.val: * `case tag => tac` focuses on the goal with case name `tag` and solves it using `tac`, or else fails. * `case tag x₁ ... xₙ => tac` additionally renames the `n` most recent hypotheses with inaccessible names to the given names. * `case tag₁ | tag₂ => tac` is equivalent to `(case tag₁ => tac); (case tag₂ => tac)`. -/
"case "
" => "

CommandDoccommentNode.comment: `case'` is similar to the `case tag => tac` tactic, but does not ensure the goal has been solved after applying `tac`, nor admits the goal if `tac` failed. Recall that `case` closes the goal using `sorry` when `tac` fails, and the tactic execution is not interrupted. -/

AtomNode.val: `case'` is similar to the `case tag => tac` tactic, but does not ensure the goal has been solved after applying `tac`, nor admits the goal if `tac` failed. Recall that `case` closes the goal using `sorry` when `tac` fails, and the tactic execution is not interrupted. -/
"case' "
" => "

CommandDoccommentNode.comment: `next => tac` focuses on the next goal and solves it using `tac`, or else fails. `next x₁ ... xₙ => tac` additionally renames the `n` most recent hypotheses with inaccessible names to the given names. -/

AtomNode.val: `next => tac` focuses on the next goal and solves it using `tac`, or else fails. `next x₁ ... xₙ => tac` additionally renames the `n` most recent hypotheses with inaccessible names to the given names. -/
" => "

CommandDoccommentNode.comment: `focus tac` focuses on the main goal, suppressing all other goals, and runs `tac` on it. Usually `· tac`, which enforces that the goal is closed by `tac`, should be preferred. -/

AtomNode.val: `focus tac` focuses on the main goal, suppressing all other goals, and runs `tac` on it. Usually `· tac`, which enforces that the goal is closed by `tac`, should be preferred. -/
"focus "

CommandDoccommentNode.comment: `conv => cs` runs `cs` in sequence on the target `t`, resulting in `t'`, which becomes the new target subgoal. -/

AtomNode.val: `conv => cs` runs `cs` in sequence on the target `t`, resulting in `t'`, which becomes the new target subgoal. -/
" => "

CommandDoccommentNode.comment: `· conv` focuses on the main conv goal and tries to solve it using `s`. -/

AtomNode.val: `· conv` focuses on the main conv goal and tries to solve it using `s`. -/
"·"

CommandDoccommentNode.comment: `fail_if_success t` fails if the tactic `t` succeeds. -/

AtomNode.val: `fail_if_success t` fails if the tactic `t` succeeds. -/
"fail_if_success "

CommandDoccommentNode.comment: `rw [rules]` applies the given list of rewrite rules to the target. See the `rw` tactic for more information. -/

AtomNode.val: `rw [rules]` applies the given list of rewrite rules to the target. See the `rw` tactic for more information. -/

CommandDoccommentNode.comment: `erw [rules]` is a shorthand for `rw (transparency := .default) [rules]`. This does rewriting up to unfolding of regular definitions (by comparison to regular `rw` which only unfolds `@[reducible]` definitions). -/

AtomNode.val: `erw [rules]` is a shorthand for `rw (transparency := .default) [rules]`. This does rewriting up to unfolding of regular definitions (by comparison to regular `rw` which only unfolds `@[reducible]` definitions). -/

CommandDoccommentNode.comment: `args` traverses into all arguments. Synonym for `congr`. -/

AtomNode.val: `args` traverses into all arguments. Synonym for `congr`. -/

CommandDoccommentNode.comment: `left` traverses into the left argument. Synonym for `lhs`. -/

AtomNode.val: `left` traverses into the left argument. Synonym for `lhs`. -/

CommandDoccommentNode.comment: `right` traverses into the right argument. Synonym for `rhs`. -/

AtomNode.val: `right` traverses into the right argument. Synonym for `rhs`. -/

CommandDoccommentNode.comment: `intro` traverses into binders. Synonym for `ext`. -/

AtomNode.val: `intro` traverses into binders. Synonym for `ext`. -/

CommandDoccommentNode.comment: `enter [arg, ...]` is a compact way to describe a path to a subterm. It is a shorthand for other conv tactics as follows: * `enter [i]` is equivalent to `arg i`. * `enter [@i]` is equivalent to `arg @i`. * `enter [x]` (where `x` is an identifier) is equivalent to `ext x`. For example, given the target `f (g a (fun x => x b))`, `enter [1, 2, x, 1]` will traverse to the subterm `b`. -/

AtomNode.val: `enter [arg, ...]` is a compact way to describe a path to a subterm. It is a shorthand for other conv tactics as follows: * `enter [i]` is equivalent to `arg i`. * `enter [@i]` is equivalent to `arg @i`. * `enter [x]` (where `x` is an identifier) is equivalent to `ext x`. For example, given the target `f (g a (fun x => x b))`, `enter [1, 2, x, 1]` will traverse to the subterm `b`. -/
" ["

CommandDoccommentNode.comment: The `apply thm` conv tactic is the same as `apply thm` the tactic. There are no restrictions on `thm`, but strange results may occur if `thm` cannot be reasonably interpreted as proving one equality from a list of others. -/

AtomNode.val: The `apply thm` conv tactic is the same as `apply thm` the tactic. There are no restrictions on `thm`, but strange results may occur if `thm` cannot be reasonably interpreted as proving one equality from a list of others. -/
"apply "

CommandDoccommentNode.comment: `first | conv | ...` runs each `conv` until one succeeds, or else fails. -/

AtomNode.val: `first | conv | ...` runs each `conv` until one succeeds, or else fails. -/
"first "
"| "

CommandDoccommentNode.comment: `try tac` runs `tac` and succeeds even if `tac` failed. -/

AtomNode.val: `try tac` runs `tac` and succeeds even if `tac` failed. -/
"try "

CommandDoccommentNode.comment: `tac <;> tac'` runs `tac` on the main goal and `tac'` on each produced goal, concatenating all goals produced by `tac'`. -/

AtomNode.val: `tac <;> tac'` runs `tac` on the main goal and `tac'` on each produced goal, concatenating all goals produced by `tac'`. -/
" <;> "

CommandDoccommentNode.comment: `repeat convs` runs the sequence `convs` repeatedly until it fails to apply. -/

AtomNode.val: `repeat convs` runs the sequence `convs` repeatedly until it fails to apply. -/
"repeat "

CommandDoccommentNode.comment:
Extracts `let` and `let_fun` expressions from within the target expression. This is the conv mode version of the `extract_lets` tactic.
- `extract_lets` extracts all the lets from the target. - `extract_lets x y z` extracts all the lets from the target and uses `x`, `y`, and `z` for the first names. Using `_` for a name leaves it unnamed.
Limitation: the extracted local declarations do not persist outside of the `conv` goal. See also `lift_lets`, which does not extract lets as local declarations. -/

AtomNode.val:
Extracts `let` and `let_fun` expressions from within the target expression. This is the conv mode version of the `extract_lets` tactic.
- `extract_lets` extracts all the lets from the target. - `extract_lets x y z` extracts all the lets from the target and uses `x`, `y`, and `z` for the first names. Using `_` for a name leaves it unnamed.
Limitation: the extracted local declarations do not persist outside of the `conv` goal. See also `lift_lets`, which does not extract lets as local declarations. -/
"extract_lets "

CommandDoccommentNode.comment: Lifts `let` and `let_fun` expressions within the target expression as far out as possible. This is the conv mode version of the `lift_lets` tactic. -/

AtomNode.val: Lifts `let` and `let_fun` expressions within the target expression as far out as possible. This is the conv mode version of the `lift_lets` tactic. -/
"lift_lets "

CommandDoccommentNode.comment:
`conv => ...` allows the user to perform targeted rewriting on a goal or hypothesis, by focusing on particular subexpressions.
See <https://lean-lang.org/theorem_proving_in_lean4/conv.html> for more details.
Basic forms: * `conv => cs` will rewrite the goal with conv tactics `cs`. * `conv at h => cs` will rewrite hypothesis `h`. * `conv in pat => cs` will rewrite the first subexpression matching `pat` (see `pattern`). -/

AtomNode.trailing: -- HACK: put this at the end so that references to `conv` above -- refer to the syntax category instead of this syntax
AtomNode.val:
`conv => ...` allows the user to perform targeted rewriting on a goal or hypothesis, by focusing on particular subexpressions.
See <https://lean-lang.org/theorem_proving_in_lean4/conv.html> for more details.
Basic forms: * `conv => cs` will rewrite the goal with conv tactics `cs`. * `conv at h => cs` will rewrite hypothesis `h`. * `conv in pat => cs` will rewrite the first subexpression matching `pat` (see `pattern`). -/
" at "
" in "
" => "

CommandDoccommentNode.comment: `norm_cast` tactic in `conv` mode. -/

AtomNode.val: `norm_cast` tactic in `conv` mode. -/

Comment.text: `conv` is the syntax category for a "conv tactic", where "conv" is short for conversion. A conv tactic is a program which receives a target, printed as `| a`, and is tasked with coming up with some term `b` and a proof of `a = b`. It is mainly used for doing targeted term transformations, for example rewriting only on the left side of an equality. -/
-- Order is important: a missing `conv` proof should not be parsed as `{ <missing> }`, -- automatically closing goals
The `*` occurrence list means to apply to all occurrences of the pattern. -/
A list `1 2 4` of occurrences means to apply to the first, second, and fourth occurrence of the pattern. -/
An occurrence specification, either `*` or a list of numbers. The default is `[1]`. -/
`with_annotate_state stx t` annotates the lexical range of `stx : Syntax` with the initial and final state of running tactic `t`. -/
`skip` does nothing. -/

Traverses into the left subterm of a binary operator.
In general, for an `n`-ary operator, it traverses into the second to last argument. It is a synonym for `arg -2`. -/

Traverses into the right subterm of a binary operator.
In general, for an `n`-ary operator, it traverses into the last argument. It is a synonym for `arg -1`. -/
Traverses into the function of a (unary) function application. For example, `| f a b` turns into `| f a`. (Use `arg 0` to traverse into `f`.) -/

Reduces the target to Weak Head Normal Form. This reduces definitions in "head position" until a constructor is exposed. For example, `List.map f [a, b, c]` weak head normalizes to `f a :: List.map f [b, c]`. -/
Expands let-declarations and let-variables. -/
Puts term in normal form, this tactic is meant for debugging purposes only. -/

Performs one step of "congruence", which takes a term and produces subgoals for all the function arguments. For example, if the target is `f x y` then `congr` produces two subgoals, one for `x` and one for `y`. -/

* `arg i` traverses into the `i`'th argument of the target. For example if the target is `f a b c d` then `arg 1` traverses to `a` and `arg 3` traverses to `c`. The index may be negative; `arg -1` traverses into the last argument, `arg -2` into the second-to-last argument, and so on. * `arg @i` is the same as `arg i` but it counts all arguments instead of just the explicit arguments. * `arg 0` traverses into the function. If the target is `f a b c d`, `arg 0` traverses into `f`. -/
`ext x` traverses into a binder (a `fun x => e` or `∀ x, e` expression) to target `e`, introducing name `x` in the process. -/
`change t'` replaces the target `t` with `t'`, assuming `t` and `t'` are definitionally equal. -/

`delta id1 id2 ...` unfolds all occurrences of `id1`, `id2`, ... in the target. Like the `delta` tactic, this ignores any definitional equations and uses primitive delta-reduction instead, which may result in leaking implementation details. Users should prefer `unfold` for unfolding definitions. -/

* `unfold id` unfolds all occurrences of definition `id` in the target. * `unfold id1 id2 ...` is equivalent to `unfold id1; unfold id2; ...`.
Definitions can be either global or local definitions.
For non-recursive global definitions, this tactic is identical to `delta`. For recursive global definitions, it uses the "unfolding lemma" `id.eq_def`, which is generated for each recursive definition, to unfold according to the recursive definition given by the user. Only one level of unfolding is performed, in contrast to `simp only [id]`, which unfolds definition `id` recursively.
This is the `conv` version of the `unfold` tactic. -/

* `pattern pat` traverses to the first subterm of the target that matches `pat`. * `pattern (occs := *) pat` traverses to every subterm of the target that matches `pat` which is not contained in another match of `pat`. It generates one subgoal for each matching subterm. * `pattern (occs := 1 2 4) pat` matches occurrences `1, 2, 4` of `pat` and produces three subgoals. Occurrences are numbered left to right from the outside in.
Note that skipping an occurrence of `pat` will traverse inside that subexpression, which means it may find more matches and this can affect the numbering of subsequent pattern matches. For example, if we are searching for `f _` in `f (f a) = f b`: * `occs := 1 2` (and `occs := *`) returns `| f (f a)` and `| f b` * `occs := 2` returns `| f a` * `occs := 2 3` returns `| f a` and `| f b` * `occs := 1 3` is an error, because after skipping `f b` there is no third match. -/
`rw [thm]` rewrites the target using `thm`. See the `rw` tactic for more information. -/
`simp [thm]` performs simplification using `thm` and marked `@[simp]` lemmas. See the `simp` tactic for more information. -/
`simp?` takes the same arguments as `simp`, but reports an equivalent call to `simp only` that would be sufficient to close the goal. See the `simp?` tactic for more information. -/

`dsimp` is the definitional simplifier in `conv`-mode. It differs from `simp` in that it only applies theorems that hold by reflexivity.
Examples:
```lean example (a : Nat): (0 + 0) = a - a := by conv => lhs dsimp rw [← Nat.sub_self a] ``` -/
`simp_match` simplifies match expressions. For example, ``` match [a, b] with | [] => 0 | hd :: tl => hd ``` simplifies to `a`. -/
Executes the given tactic block without converting `conv` goal into a regular goal. -/
Focuses, converts the `conv` goal `⊢ lhs` into a regular goal `⊢ lhs = rhs`, and then executes the given tactic block. -/
Executes the given conv block without converting regular goal into a `conv` goal. -/
`{ convs }` runs the list of `convs` on the current target, and any subgoals that remain are trivially closed by `skip`. -/
`(convs)` runs the `convs` in sequence on the current list of targets. This is pure grouping with no added effects. -/
`rfl` closes one conv goal "trivially", by using reflexivity (that is, no rewriting). -/
`done` succeeds iff there are no goals remaining. -/
`trace_state` prints the current goal state. -/
`all_goals tac` runs `tac` on each goal, concatenating the resulting goals, if any. -/
`any_goals tac` applies the tactic `tac` to every goal, and succeeds if at least one application succeeds. -/

* `case tag => tac` focuses on the goal with case name `tag` and solves it using `tac`, or else fails. * `case tag x₁ ... xₙ => tac` additionally renames the `n` most recent hypotheses with inaccessible names to the given names. * `case tag₁ | tag₂ => tac` is equivalent to `(case tag₁ => tac); (case tag₂ => tac)`. -/

`case'` is similar to the `case tag => tac` tactic, but does not ensure the goal has been solved after applying `tac`, nor admits the goal if `tac` failed. Recall that `case` closes the goal using `sorry` when `tac` fails, and the tactic execution is not interrupted. -/

`next => tac` focuses on the next goal and solves it using `tac`, or else fails. `next x₁ ... xₙ => tac` additionally renames the `n` most recent hypotheses with inaccessible names to the given names. -/
`focus tac` focuses on the main goal, suppressing all other goals, and runs `tac` on it. Usually `· tac`, which enforces that the goal is closed by `tac`, should be preferred. -/
`conv => cs` runs `cs` in sequence on the target `t`, resulting in `t'`, which becomes the new target subgoal. -/
`· conv` focuses on the main conv goal and tries to solve it using `s`. -/
`fail_if_success t` fails if the tactic `t` succeeds. -/
`rw [rules]` applies the given list of rewrite rules to the target. See the `rw` tactic for more information. -/

`erw [rules]` is a shorthand for `rw (transparency := .default) [rules]`. This does rewriting up to unfolding of regular definitions (by comparison to regular `rw` which only unfolds `@[reducible]` definitions). -/
`args` traverses into all arguments. Synonym for `congr`. -/
`left` traverses into the left argument. Synonym for `lhs`. -/
`right` traverses into the right argument. Synonym for `rhs`. -/
`intro` traverses into binders. Synonym for `ext`. -/

`enter [arg, ...]` is a compact way to describe a path to a subterm. It is a shorthand for other conv tactics as follows: * `enter [i]` is equivalent to `arg i`. * `enter [@i]` is equivalent to `arg @i`. * `enter [x]` (where `x` is an identifier) is equivalent to `ext x`. For example, given the target `f (g a (fun x => x b))`, `enter [1, 2, x, 1]` will traverse to the subterm `b`. -/

The `apply thm` conv tactic is the same as `apply thm` the tactic. There are no restrictions on `thm`, but strange results may occur if `thm` cannot be reasonably interpreted as proving one equality from a list of others. -/
-- TODO: error if non-conv subgoals?
`first | conv | ...` runs each `conv` until one succeeds, or else fails. -/
`try tac` runs `tac` and succeeds even if `tac` failed. -/
`tac <;> tac'` runs `tac` on the main goal and `tac'` on each produced goal, concatenating all goals produced by `tac'`. -/
`repeat convs` runs the sequence `convs` repeatedly until it fails to apply. -/

Extracts `let` and `let_fun` expressions from within the target expression. This is the conv mode version of the `extract_lets` tactic.
- `extract_lets` extracts all the lets from the target. - `extract_lets x y z` extracts all the lets from the target and uses `x`, `y`, and `z` for the first names. Using `_` for a name leaves it unnamed.
Limitation: the extracted local declarations do not persist outside of the `conv` goal. See also `lift_lets`, which does not extract lets as local declarations. -/
Lifts `let` and `let_fun` expressions within the target expression as far out as possible. This is the conv mode version of the `lift_lets` tactic. -/

`conv => ...` allows the user to perform targeted rewriting on a goal or hypothesis, by focusing on particular subexpressions.
See <https://lean-lang.org/theorem_proving_in_lean4/conv.html> for more details.
Basic forms: * `conv => cs` will rewrite the goal with conv tactics `cs`. * `conv at h => cs` will rewrite hypothesis `h`. * `conv in pat => cs` will rewrite the first subexpression matching `pat` (see `pattern`). -/
-- HACK: put this at the end so that references to `conv` above -- refer to the syntax category instead of this syntax
`norm_cast` tactic in `conv` mode. -/
